item.title: CV
item.description:
2021-2023 Postdoc, Harvard Department of Government + Center for the Environment

2021 PhD, American Politics and Methods, University of Wisconsin–Madison

  • Committee: Susan Yackee (Chair), Eleanor Powell, Alex Tahk, David Weimer, Miriam Seifter
  • Dissertation: Public Pressure Campaigns and Bureaucratic Policymaking
  • Book project: Public Pressure: How Groups Organize to Affect Policymaking

2013 M.E.Sc. in Environmental Policy and Law, Yale University

4 peer-reviewed publications (2 articles, 2 chapters)

  • 2022 - “Campaign Contributions and Bureaucratic Oversight: A Case Study of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission” with Eleanor Powell and Justin Grimmer in Accountability Reconsidered, Cambridge University Press

  • 2020 - “Data and Methods for Analyzing Interest Group Influence in Rulemaking” with Daniel Carpenter, Brian Libgober, Steven Rashin. Interest Groups & Advocacy 9:425–435

  • 2020 - “Do Private Regulations Ratchet Up? How to Distinguish Types of Regulatory Stringency and Patterns of Change” with Ben Cashore and Constance McDermott in Organization & Environment 33:1 96–125

  • 2015 - “Non-domestic Sources of Canadian Boreal Forest Policy: Integrating Theories of Internationalization and Pathways of Policy Change” with Irene Scher and Ben Cashore

3 papers under review

  • JMP: “Making Policy About Distributive Justice: The Environmental Justice Movement’s Impact on Agency Rulemaking” (AESS 2018, APSA 2021)

  • “Mapping Literature with Networks: An Application to Redistricting” with Adeline Lo, Kyler Hudson, Kenneth R. Mayer (PolMeth 2022, R&R at Political Analysis)

  • “The Effects of Shifting Priorities and Capacity on Policy Work and Constituency Service: Evidence from a Census of Legislator Requests to U.S. Federal Agencies” with Justin Grimmer and Eleanor Powell (APSA 2020)

Working papers on Judicial Review (APSA 2022), Text Analysis (PolMeth 2022), Climate Change (Climate Pipeline Conference), Constituent Service (APSA 2020), Lobbying Coalitions (SPSA 2019)

3 R packages: netlit aids literature reviews with network analysis, legislators finds legislator names in messy text , congressionalrecord to scrape, parse, & analyze the Congressional Record

AWARDS: APSA 2021 Best Paper in Public Administration for “Inequality in Administrative Democracy: Methods and Evidence from Financial Rulemaking” (coauthored, APSA 2021), Levin Center Congressional Oversight Fellow ($10k, 2021-2022), Best Dissertation in American Politics, UW-Madison (2021), NSF DDRIG ($15k, 2020), Exceptional Mentorship Award, UW–Madison

TEACHING: Instructor of record for Public Policy (Undergraduate, 2019, 2020) and Statistical Computing in Political Science (Graduate, 2019) + 6 semesters as TA at UW and Yale
